author: Soumya Das
text:
Despite sticking to its pre-2011 stand on fast tracking industrialisation, the Communist Party of India (Marxist)-led Left Front has taken a “cautious” approach to land acquisition in its draft manifesto for the West Bengal polls.

“Land acquisition for industry has to be dealt with carefully,” states the manifesto. It emphasises on providing a “lucrative price” and a job to one member from each of the families affected by land acquisition.

The draft manifesto states that “elaborate discussions” have to take place between the State Government and the residents of the area where the land will be acquired. This assumes significance in the backdrop of the “forced land acquisition” at Singur for the Tata Motors’ car factory that became the rallying point for the Trinamool Congress (TMC)-led Opposition in the 2011 polls. The agitation played a key role in ending the 34-year-long Left Front rule in Bengal and brought the TMC to power.

As for employment generation, the manifesto says there will be “greater emphasis” on boosting small and medium scale industries, but is guarded on large industries. It merely says “there should be effort also to set up large industries.”

Seeks feedback

For the first time, the Left Front has put its draft election manifesto on its website and has invited comments from the general public.
title: Left manifesto cautious on land acquisition
